evidence_span: Zircaloys can be melted successfully in a $5 0 0 \mathrm { - } \mathsf { m m }$ ingot diameter EB furnace at melting rates between 200 and $5 0 0 ~ \mathrm { k g / h }$ without special composition precautions with respect to tin

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: This configuration will also dissolve zirconium nitride precipitates successfully

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: electrode is prepared by the electron-beam (EB) welding together of compacted zirconium sponge (containing packets of alloy elements), sections of scrap vacuum-arc remelt (VAR) ingot, and compacted scrap zirconium alloy pieces

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: EB welding is carried out in horizontal vacuum chambers and results in a $3 5 \mathrm { - c m }$ -diameter electrode

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: electrode is then melted by VAR into a solid $4 3 \mathrm { - c m }$ -diameter ingot

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: second-melt VAR step, which produces a 51 or ${ 5 8 - c m }$ -diameter ingot

evidence_span: second-melt VAR step, which produces a 51 or ${ 5 8 - c m }$ -diameter ingot
